title: Kain panjang

  title_text: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features two different but related designs on each half of the kain. The left side of the batik features roses and orchids along the left and bottom
 with several birds flying above the flowers. The right side of the batik features irises and orchirds along the top and right of the batik
 with butterflies flying below the flowers. The floral design is set against a densely decorated brown background filled with intricate tendrils and florals. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan birds (motifs) flower (motif) cultural diffusion foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format
 comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The main floral motif on one side consists of roses on one side and irises on the other.  The two halves are also marked by different border designs
 both in terms of colour and choice of background fillers.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This batik is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features two different but related designs on each half of the kain. The left side of the batik features roses and orchids along the left and bottom, with several birds flying above the flowers. The right side of the batik features irises and orchirds along the top and right of the batik, with butterflies flying below the flowers. The floral design is set against a densely decorated brown background filled with intricate tendrils and florals. There is a signature at the top-left of the batik.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This batik is structured in the pagi-sore format, comprising two different but related designs on each half of the kain panjang.  The main floral motif on one side consists of roses on one side and irises on the other.  The two halves are also marked by different border designs, both in terms of colour and choice of background fillers.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This batik is signed “Batik Kesenian Liem Siok Hien Kudus”.
